articles.headline: Refugees Discover 2 Americas: One That Hates, and One That Heals
articles.snippet: Amid rising attacks on members of minority groups across the United States, refugees find themselves comparing the threats they fled to those that might still emerge.
articles.abstract: Amid rising attacks on members of minority groups across the United States, refugees find themselves comparing the threats they fled to those that might still emerge.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNDALK, Md. — Ra’ad and Hutham Lalqaraghuli are no longer sure which America they’re a part of.

articles.headline: Critics See Stephen Bannon, Trump’s Pick for Strategist, as Voice of Racism
articles.snippet: People took to Twitter to lament what they said was a frightening normalization of the fringe views that Mr. Bannon promoted as the chairman of Breitbart News.
articles.abstract: People took to Twitter to lament what they said was a frightening normalization of the fringe views that Mr. Bannon promoted as the chairman of Breitbart News.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A fierce chorus of critics denounced President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday for appointing Stephen K. Bannon, a nationalist media mogul, to a top White House position, even as President Obama described Mr. Trump as “pragmatic,” not ideological, and held out hope that he would rise to the challenge of the presidency.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Gwen Ifill, Political Reporter and Co-Anchor of ‘PBS NewsHour,’ Dies at 61
articles.snippet: Ms. Ifill reported for The Washington Post, The New York Times and NBC News before becoming a PBS presence and debate moderator.
articles.abstract: Ms. Ifill reported for The Washington Post, The New York Times and NBC News before becoming a PBS presence and debate moderator.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gwen Ifill, a groundbreaking journalist who covered the White House, Congress and national campaigns during three decades for The Washington Post, The New York Times, NBC and, most prominently, PBS, died on Monday at a hospice in Washington. She was 61.

articles.headline: Trump’s Choice of Stephen Bannon Is Nod to Anti-Washington Base
articles.snippet: Mr. Bannon, the former head of Breitbart News, will be President-elect Trump’s senior adviser, an appointment that has drawn criticism.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bannon, the former head of Breitbart News, will be President-elect Trump’s senior adviser, an appointment that has drawn criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In naming Stephen K. Bannon to a senior White House post, President-elect Donald J. Trump has elevated the hard-right nationalist movement that Mr. Bannon has nurtured for years from the fringes of American politics to its very heart, a remarkable shift that has further intensified concern about the new administration’s direction.

articles.headline: Mary Jo White to Step Down as S.E.C. Chief
articles.snippet: Other financial regulators are expected to follow suit, giving the Trump administration an opening to shift the government’s approach to policing the industry.
articles.abstract: Other financial regulators are expected to follow suit, giving the Trump administration an opening to shift the government’s approach to policing the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street regulators began an exodus from Washington on Monday as Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced plans to leave the agency.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Ahead of Trump Presidency, Global Investors Sell Bonds and Grab Stocks
articles.snippet: Sovereign wealth funds and hedge funds, as well as retirees’ accounts, restructure portfolios to profit from what they expect will be a free-spending administration.
articles.abstract: Sovereign wealth funds and hedge funds, as well as retirees’ accounts, restructure portfolios to profit from what they expect will be a free-spending administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global investors have rendered their verdict on Donald J. Trump as president: Sell government bonds and pile into stocks that will benefit the most from a resurgent United States economy.

articles.headline: Google and Facebook Take Aim at Fake News Sites
articles.snippet: After criticism that they might have allowed fake news to influence the 2016 election, the companies are banning such sites from using their advertising services.
articles.abstract: After criticism that they might have allowed fake news to influence the 2016 election, the companies are banning such sites from using their advertising services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last week, two of the world’s biggest internet companies have faced mounting criticism over how fake news on their sites may have influenced the presidential election’s outcome.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield, Mike Isaac and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Far-Flung Holdings Raise Potential for Conflicts of Interest
articles.snippet: The conflicts are in many ways as complex as his business empire, adding a heightened degree of difficulty for Mr. Trump to separate his official duties from his private business affairs.
articles.abstract: The conflicts are in many ways as complex as his business empire, adding a heightened degree of difficulty for Mr. Trump to separate his official duties from his private business affairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just a few blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House sits the Trump International Hotel, one of the newest luxury additions to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s real estate empire, and perhaps the most visible symbol of the ethical quandary he now confronts.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Secret Back Door in Some U.S. Phones Sent Data to China, Analysts Say
articles.snippet: Security contractors recently discovered preinstalled software in some Android phones that monitors where users go, whom they talk to and what they write in texts.
articles.abstract: Security contractors recently discovered preinstalled software in some Android phones that monitors where users go, whom they talk to and what they write in texts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For about $50, you can get a smartphone with a high-definition display, fast data service and, according to security contractors, a secret feature: a backdoor that sends all your text messages to China every 72 hours.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Biggest Spike in Traffic Deaths in 50 Years? Blame Apps
articles.snippet: Highway deaths have surged in the last two years, and experts put much of the blame on in-car use of smartphones and dashboard apps.
articles.abstract: Highway deaths have surged in the last two years, and experts put much of the blame on in-car use of smartphones and dashboard apps.
articles.lead_paragraph: The messaging app Snapchat allows motorists to post photos that record the speed of the vehicle. The navigation app Waze rewards drivers with points when they report traffic jams and accidents. Even the game Pokémon Go has drivers searching for virtual creatures on the nation’s highways.

articles.headline: Firings and Discord Put Trump Transition Team in a State of Disarray
articles.snippet: The uncertain start to what is normally a rapid and meticulously planned transfer of power could have big implications for the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: The uncertain start to what is normally a rapid and meticulously planned transfer of power could have big implications for the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition was in disarray on Tuesday, marked by firings, infighting and revelations that American allies were blindly dialing in to Trump Tower to try to reach the soon-to-be-leader of the free world.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Mark Mazzetti and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Rudolph Giuliani’s Business Ties Viewed as Red Flag for Secretary of State Job
articles.snippet: Mr. Giuliani, a loyal supporter of President-elect Donald J. Trump, would be a startling choice to be the nation’s chief diplomat, given his background.
articles.abstract: Mr. Giuliani, a loyal supporter of President-elect Donald J. Trump, would be a startling choice to be the nation’s chief diplomat, given his background.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani, facing a flood of questions about whether his business dealings should disqualify him from being named President-elect Donald J. Trump’s secretary of state, on Tuesday defended his lucrative 15 years in the private sector as a credential for the job.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Eric Lipton and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Trump Campaign’s Easy Answers Confront Hard Reality
articles.snippet: The president-elect is being forced to acknowledge that his straightforward solutions are less straightforward than he promised.
articles.abstract: The president-elect is being forced to acknowledge that his straightforward solutions are less straightforward than he promised.
articles.lead_paragraph: The harvest had just begun when agents from the Immigration and Naturalization Service stormed across the onion fields of Vidalia, Ga., in 1998, sweeping up 21 immigrants who were trudging behind tractors without legal authorization to work in the United States, pulling onions out of the ground for 75 cents per 50-pound bag.
